CARIANI: HST.725 is a course
really aimed at surveying music

perception and cognition.
Much of our curriculum nowadays

in neuroscience and biology and
psychology is very specialized.

We look at very small problems,
very compartmentalized

problems.
The knowledge is parcelized

into very small pieces.
And the big picture gets lost.

So an important part,
I think, of any pedagogy,

in any university really is to
get students to think

synthetically,
to think about what is the

nature of our auditory systems
and our brains such that music

has the effects that it does.
So a typical class would be a

lecture.
And we had many demonstrations.

I would often use my computer
oscilloscope.

We would look at the structure
of sounds.

We used animations from the
music animation machine to

illustrate both the horizontal
and vertical structure of music.

We would listen to musical
pieces that illustrated

particular aspects of music
perception and cognition.

I would talk for about an hour
going over the area of the topic

of the day which could be
something like the perception of

pitch or tambour or consonance
or harmony or scene analysis,

grouping processes,
something like that.

And the course was small enough
so that we could have a back and

forth.
And many of the students,

it is a graduate course,
and we had some undergraduates

also.
Many of the students already

were dealing with these issues
in their own work.

Well, it is a small elective
course and it was an

experimental course,
as I said, that we taught for

the first time last spring.
And what I wanted to do was to

structure the course in a way
that we would both

systematically cover the
perception and cognition of

music, music psychology,
but that would allow the

students a great deal of freedom
in choosing their own aspect of

music psychology that they
wanted to look into.

So the main work that the
students do is their own term

project.
And that can be a review paper

that covers extensively some
area of music perception and

cognition.
It can be an experimental

project where students can go
and actually do experiments or

surveys, psychology of music,
or it could be a music project,

a music composition that
illustrates the principles of

music perception and talks about
those.

Or a simulation or a model,
scientific model that

illuminates and explores some
aspect of the mechanisms that

are involved.
So the bulk of the student work

in this case was a term project.
We also had an oral

presentation students gave on a
paper that they chose in the

course.
And we also had a large problem

set and take-home test.
And what I had in mind was to

systematically look at auditory
perception and auditory

cognition with music as the
object of that perception and

cognition.
So the intension is very much

kind of in the spirit of Hermann
von Helmholtz's on the

sensations of tone as a basis
for a psychology of music,

in that spirit to
systematically go through,

look at the structure of the
musical stimulus,

the structure of music as a
sound object.

And then look at the
perception, how do we perceive

music, what are the qualities of
the sounds that we hear,

how do they interact?
And then look at the underlying

neural representations and
computations that allow us to

apprehend that structure and
appreciate it.
